Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2011 07:52AM etherize wrote: This is fascinating. A woman in my support group was reading a book about bc research in Europe and she mentioned this theory that women with bc have chronically low body temperatures. Everyone in the group reported having low body temperature! I haven't read this whole thread yet .... Just googled low body temp and breast cancer and found it. :) Thanks for the info!
Posts.Title: Low Body Temperature anyone? MBJ mapat

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2013 07:20PM etherize wrote: {{{{Hugs}}} to you, LKSHER!  I am so sorry you are going through this.  But you will get through it.  As lemon said, the ER+/PR+ and HER2- is good, as is the grade 1.  The chemo, radiation and hormone treatment are designed to get any stray cells that may be lurking after surgery.  So, if you can, try not to worry about the bit that didn't light up on the PET scan.  They'll remove it in the surgery, and anything else will be zapped with the other treatments. It sucks to get a cancer diagnosis when you don't have a family history and you've done everything "right."  But unfortunately bc doesn't discriminate.  There's no use wondering how/why you got it (although we all do at some point). I don't know how you feel about meds, but a lot of us have gotten through the initial days of terror with the help of Ativan (lorazepam).  It can really help you get the rest you need, and help keep your mind from completely going off the rails. One day at a time -- you WILL get through this!
Posts.Title: Frozen with Fear LKSHER Ariom

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2011 07:53PM etherize wrote: Caryn (exbrnxgrl), thanks for the info on Kaiser and the second opinion process.  It's very helpful! I'm not sure I can afford a second opinion outside of Kaiser, but I'll definitely look into it.
Posts.Title: A nearly impossible decision etherize Carola32

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2011 09:16AM etherize wrote: That's why I started this thread. Apparently my surgeon won't even know the grade or stage until the surgery (lumpectomy and SNB) is done! So how can I know what I want (lumpectomy or MX)? That's what I meant by an "impossible decision." Before I got bc, I thought a lumpectomy was one operation. Now I'm learning it's rarely one operation -- it's one to get the tumor out, another one or two to clean up margins, a MX, etc. etc.! Like you said, I don't like the idea of lopping off a breast in pieces, just because I don't like the idea of so many operations. Having said that, I agree that few surgeons are scheduling surgeries just for the money. I didn't mean to imply Kaiser docs are that way; I just don't know their system well yet. From my research, it seems most surgeons recommend lumpectomies when there is a choice, just to be on the conservative side. But they'll go along with the patient if she wants an MX or even BMX. It IS cool that I get to meet with 3 docs up front. Apparently not all Kaiser locations offer this "breast cancer clinic." When the nurse said some patients don't opt to do it, my question was "WHY?!" :-)
Posts.Title: A nearly impossible decision etherize Carola32

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2011 06:48PM etherize wrote: Thanks, everybody!   I do hope this tumor is small; it looked huge on the mammogram -- definitely at least 2cm, possibly more.  But the nurse said you can't tell from the mammo; she said it could even be smaller than what it looked like, which doesn't make sense to me ... but I'll find out soon enough, I guess. ;-) Rockym, it would be cool to take a vacation prior to surgery!  Sounds like that was a great decision you made.   exbrnxgrl, one thing I like about Kaiser so far is you can look at your doctor's home page and see where they got their education, how much experience, etc.  And, it shouldn't make a difference, but I like the fact that my BS is a woman. ;-)
Posts.Title: A nearly impossible decision etherize Carola32

Posts.Content: etherize wrote: This decision -- lumpectomy, BMX, UniMX -- seems impossible to make at the time that you have to make it. I'm meeting with a breast cancer surgeon on Thursday and was told by the nurse that "surgery is usually scheduled at that time."  But if you don't know what you're dealing with, how can you possibly decide?! From this site (breastcancer.org): "Decisions about surgery depend on many factors. You and your doctor will determine the kind of surgery that’s most appropriate for you based on the stage of the cancer, the "personality" of the cancer, and what is acceptable to you in terms of your long-term peace of mind." But they don't know the stage until they take out the tumor and test the node--at least, I won't.  I don't even have a grade yet.   The nurse said they'll probably recommend a lumpectomy and I have to get a SNB.  But the thought of lots more surgeries in the future is making me consider a mastectomy (unilateral) or even BMX.  Dx 8/17/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 9/14/2011 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel Surgery 10/17/2011 Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary Chemotherapy 12/19/2011 CMF Radiation Therapy 5/7/2012 Hormonal Therapy 6/19/2012 Femara (letrozole) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: A nearly impossible decision etherize Carola32

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 10:48AM etherize wrote: I think the last line of what raincitygirl says is important: "You have to trust your surgeon." I guess a big part of it is a gut feeling.  Mine said she was willing to do either one and I have a choice, but she strongly recommended the lumpectomy. After doing more research, I've come to the decision that a BLMX is too drastic for me right now. But if I got a recurrence in the same breast, then I'd probably go for it.
Posts.Title: A nearly impossible decision etherize Carola32

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2011 06:12PM etherize wrote: Thanks for the info, everybody.  There is no MRI scheduled for me, so ... that's not an option. exbrnxgrl, I'm with Kaiser too!  We've only had their insurance for a month, so it's all new to me.  Is the multidisciplinary team that you met with the "breast cancer clinic"?  Because that's what I'm doing on Thursday -- breast surgeon, radiation oncologist and medical oncologist. I asked about how to get a second opinion -- if I get one within Kaiser, they won't re-do the tests (biopsy, etc.) but also won't charge me.  But I wonder if I'd get an objective opinion.  On the other hand, if I go outside of the system, I may have to get another biopsy and Kaiser wouldn't pay anything.  I had a core biopsy done, and that's how I know it's ER+/PR+ and Her2neu.  But the nurse said apparently they didn't get a big enough sample to test for the grade.  (Which seems kind of weird ...)
Posts.Title: A nearly impossible decision etherize Carola32

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2011 07:49PM etherize wrote: Wow, rehm046, you must have a lot of patience and strong nerves to wait that long! :) It really helps to hear what you all have gone through.  Also the reminder that I have time to decide.  The fact that I can feel the lump and it's painful, plus my age (54) and the fact that I'm living with HIV/AIDS ... that all makes me feel I have less time (not only to decide on surgery, but less time to live). I'm not worried about looks so much (HIV does a number on that), but I'm worried about what my body can take.  It seems like multiple surgeries would be very hard on it.  I definitely don't want reconstruction.  Radiation doesn't scare me.  Chemo will be very tough with HIV, but I can handle it, I think.  At this point, I'm most afraid of surgery.  Needles/pain/hospitals/recovery are what really scares me.
Posts.Title: A nearly impossible decision etherize Carola32

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2011 08:29AM etherize wrote: Thanks, KatheW and greytcruise.  I still don't like the idea of so many surgeries, but I'm glad to know that somebody else has had a good experience with Kaiser.
Posts.Title: A nearly impossible decision etherize Carola32

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2011 09:05AM etherize wrote: Hi all, Yesterday I met with the Kaiser breast cancer team.  I really liked the BS.  She told me 80% of her lumpectomies don't require re-excisions, that the re-excision is not as big an operation as the lump, and that knowing how concerned I am about surgeries, she'd try to take a bigger margin initially, if possible, so I wouldn't have to go back.  So I've decided to go with a lumpectomy.  The bad news is there's another tiny spot further away, so she's going to do a wire-guided lump.  Gulp. The good news is they *think* the main tumor's an early stage (mammo showed 1.8cm and u/s showed 2.9cm).  I forgot to ask about the grade. As for worrying about recurrences in that breast or the other … I don't think that'll be a huge issue for me.  There are so many cancers and other dire things that people with AIDS are at high risk for, you just have to learn to deal with that uncertainty.

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2011 10:06PM etherize wrote: Thank you, ladies! coraleliz, both my BS and I wanted to avoid taking out more nodes based on the info you cited. But my MO says those studies apply to people with smaller tumors than mine.  Another reason she wants to do it is that because I have HIV and the HIV meds interact with the chemo drugs, I may not be able to finish chemo, so an aggressive lymph node surgery puts me in a better position in that case.  Finally, since my tumor was grade 3, and the cancer was expanding out of the one positive node, removing more potentially gives me more protection.  She said she consulted with two other MOs at Kaiser and they agreed with her.  I could get a second opinion from the remaining 2 MOs at Kaiser but I think they'd also agree.  And more important, I think it makes sense ... as much as I don't like doing it. Michele, thanks very much for the detailed explanation of how the drains work.  I faint easily and that sounds like something that would do it for me. ;)  But I want to know about it so I can be prepared and hopefully not fall apart. lol  The MO said 10-14 nodes ... Gotta go ... just writing about it now is making me feel faint!  Seesh!

I must be super-squeamish. It's amazing I had periods for 38 years and didn't faint each month!  lol  Just thinking about looking for blood clots in a tube coming out of my body makes me a bit queasy.  I will try not to think about it too much, but ... can't guarantee I won't. ;-)   Curlylocks, I just re-read your description -- at first I thought the whole tube was under the skin but now I see it's not. That's one bit of good news!

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2012 04:24PM etherize wrote: leelee, I am popping in here late to add my support and best wishes to you.  I also suffer from anxiety and depression.  That "feeling" you have that it's breast cancer could just as easily be your anxiety/depression speaking, not your intuition.  For me, sometimes it seems like I have more control if I think about the worst outcome -- but really all that does is make me more scared. Take a minute to pat yourself on the back for taking action!  Be proud of yourself for making that appointment.  You are strong enough to handle whatever happens.  Since you're all set to go tomorrow, try to focus on the present for now.  I would suggest getting off the computer -- even this site -- and watching a movie, or going out to eat.  :-)  I'm sending you lots of healing, positive energy!

Posts.Title: Can MLD cause lymph node swelling? etherize etherize

Posts.Content: etherize wrote: Well, if it ain't one thing, it's another.  I've been doing MLD every day after my shower.  Two or three days ago while doing MLD I noticed pain in my unaffected armpit and thought I'd just been doing the massage a little too hard.  I had an appt with a RO who did a breast and lymph node exam and he didn't notice anything (and I forgot about the pain).   Then yesterday morning I noticed a chickpea-sized painful lump in that armpit.  I did MLD more gently, trying to avoid the lump and by yesterday evening there was another, smaller lump right next to it.   I made a dr appt for tomorrow (I'm so SICK of doctors!!) but I'm wondering if the MLD caused this or what ... Have any of you every come across something like this? Dx 8/17/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 9/14/2011 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel Surgery 10/17/2011 Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary Chemotherapy 12/19/2011 CMF Radiation Therapy 5/7/2012 Hormonal Therapy 6/19/2012 Femara (letrozole) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2012 12:39PM etherize wrote: Thanks so much, Binney.  I will remember the gentle/slow bit -- your visuals make it easier.  The PT who demonstrated MLD on us in class seemed to do it a little bit more "vigorously" than kitten-petting, but I bet it was because she was in a bit of a hurry, and demonstrating on us through our clothes. Anyway, there are three lumps now but they don't hurt as much so I bet I just worked something up. Or maybe my right side lymph nodes just swelled in sympathy for the left side ones that will soon be irradiated into oblivion. ;-)
Posts.Title: Can MLD cause lymph node swelling? etherize etherize

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2012 02:29PM etherize wrote: Well, I'm sure learning about lymph nodes!  I hope my groin ones don't swell up like yours, KS1. That sounds a little disturbing -- even if it's normal, I wouldn't like to see it. ;-) Funny story:  my husband, who's a bit of a hypochondriac, noticed a sore lymph node in his neck (just on one side).  He convinced himself it was strep throat, or tonsillitis or something ... but also thought it might relate to keeping his head turned while playing guitar all day.   He sounded a little stuffy, so I "diagnosed" it as a cold virus that wasn't able to move through that node because of his head being turned.  Told him to do some of my LE exercises (not MLD -- just muscle pump, breathing, etc.).  Sure enough, that made him feel better, psychologically and physically.  I don't know if I "diagnosed" it correctly -- but after all this lymph node stuff, I sure have a lot more respect for the little buggers! :)

Posts.Title: Can MLD cause lymph node swelling? etherize etherize

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2011 10:03AM etherize wrote: Don't squeeze it. ;-)  I don't even want to press the breast that had a lumpectomy so I couldn't tell you about the hard areas.  Sounds like that might be some fluid in there -- or a hematoma.  I'd ask your doctor if that's what it could be. As for numbness -- yes!  Soreness -- yes!  And I'm 4 weeks out from my lumpectomy.  All sorts of weird little shooting pains and tingles and maybe even a little itchiness, although not much.  The numbness, soreness, tingling, shooting pains, etc. (super sensitive skin around the incision for me) all have been diminishing as the weeks go by. Ask your doctor about the blood/nipple bit -- that could be just residual stuff (my uneducated guess) and the hard swollen areas.  The rest, I think will diminish.

Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2011 05:18PM - edited Nov 3, 2011 05:19PM by etherize toomuch, thank you for your response! That's very interesting about ECE and radiation.  I'm definitely getting radiation and hormone therapy, and my MO did say the hormone therapy was the most important part of treatment (more than chemo, that is).  My MO just emailed me back and basically said she wouldn't even order the Oncotype test until I meet with the other MO for a 2nd opinion.
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2011 10:11PM etherize wrote: bdavis and toomuch, thanks for your input. I just got back from meeting the second MO, who I really liked. He is a senior MO to my regular MO and apparently he's advised her a fair amount on my case already.  (I'm going to see if I can switch to him!)  He said doing the Oncotype is fine with them if I want it, but it's not as good as MammaPrint, which it's too late for anyway.  But the most important thing is that the Oncotype would be most helpful to me if I were 100% sure that I'd do chemo if it came back with a high score.  And I'm not sure that a high or low score on that would really be THE deciding factor for me.  It's just another variable among many in what essentially has to boil down to a gut feeling.  bdavis, I already knew the chemo regimens that were on the table: T/C and CMF.  (The others have heart SEs that would be too dangerous.)  Many people do chemo and HIV meds, but my situation is more problematic.   I am on the one HIV med that has major interactions with chemo drugs (Cytoxan to some extent and Taxotere to a much greater extent).  A lot of HIV+ cancer patients can switch HIV meds during chemo, but the virus I have is resistant to almost all HIV meds.  So I'm stuck with the one that has big chemo-drug interactions.  Even going with a lower dose of chemo, there would be lots of risk with my HIV med and T/C, the most effective (but shorter) regimen of the two.  I could stay on HIV meds while doing CMF, but that's a 5-6 month stretch that's overall less effective (even if less toxic). Oh by the way, I only have 1 positive node, not two. :)  Thank heavens for small favors! This MO said the ECE is another factor but it's lower on the scale in a way.  The main issues are the size of the original tumor and the one positive node.  Even the one positive node, he said, isn't "that bad" in itself, but when you take it with the grade ... so in order of importance, it's size, node, grade, ECE, etc.    toomuch, thanks for the explanation about LVI and ECE.  Just looked on my path report and I apparently have both.  Wish I'd asked him about that, but ... I can always do that later.  He did say I was at "intermediate risk" of recurrence.   I like the way he described chemo:  it's like insurance.  Everybody pays for it, most people don't need it, but for those who do, it's a lifesaver. (Sorry this is so long, everybody!)
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2011 01:56PM etherize wrote: mnjclark, that's very interesting and surprising, what Johns Hopkins says about scans in our case ... I had both a CT scan and a bone scan.  Besty/bdavis, I am so amazed and impressed that you were able to work full-time during T/C.  Actually, I'm amazed anybody can do chemo and work at all! I am still having such a hard time trying to decide about whether to do chemo or not.  I just don't know if I'll be strong enough for it.  I met with the HIV pharmacist, who insists I can (and should) stop all HIV meds if I do chemo -- although no other patients at Kaiser Santa Rosa have done that (they've all been able to switch HIV meds but I can't due to virus resistance.) So my choice is:  contain HIV or try to stop cancer.  Waaah.....! Today I meet with another MO in the same dept (can't afford to go outside of Kaiser).  I also asked my MO for the Oncotype test (she offered) but after reading DeannaM's post above, I'm worried because I also had extracapsular invasion on my one positive node.  My MO didn't specifically say that meant it would be more likely to recur, although she did say it was bad. Every hour I change my mind on which way to go!  Right now I'm leaning toward chemo. Oh, does anybody here know if Kaiser will pay for Neulasta shots instead of Neupogen?  I really, really would much prefer one shot to many.
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Caryn, I think you replied to my whining about the drain in another thread.  :/   I just talked to the surgery nurse and she explained a little bit about it, said it'll probably be in for 7-10 days, depending on fluid output.  She asked what about it made me queasy.  My answer is, what part of it wouldn't make somebody queasy?!   lol I'm going to make sure there's a chair in the bathroom so I can sit down in case I feel faint!

Posts.Title: More Tips (and a Shopping List) for Getting Through Chemo rock MinusTwo

Posts.Content: etherize wrote: Hello everybody, I never thought I'd be posting on a breast cancer forum but I guess most of you never did, either. ;) I'm 54, post-menopausal and recently had my first mammogram.  Why did I wait so long?  Because I have AIDS (and no, I never used needles or slept around ... just had unprotected sex with one wrong guy back in 1982, when they didn't even know heterosexuals could get it). Anyway, I didn't even know I had HIV until 1995 when I got very sick.   Now, after 15 years of living with AIDS (and 29 years of living with HIV), I've finally got my immune system in fairly good shape.  I take several medications and deal with a number of side effects of the disease and the drugs, but I'm not on death's doorstep anymore.   My husband (who remains HIV-negative, after 24 years of marriage) and I switched to a new insurance company in July and I figured it was time to stop putting off the mammogram.  Sure enough, I was called back for another mammo and an ultrasound.  The sonographer pointed out a lump that's easily to feel and seems big to me (it's also a little tender).  I never felt it because I rarely do BSEs! When they finished the ultrasound, the radiologist came in and said I needed a biopsy.  I asked if I could put it off (knowing she'd probably say no), and asked, "Is it serious?  Is it cancer?"  and she said, "It's serious."     I studied the sonogram images carefully, and when I got home I looked up online sonogram pictures of malignant masses.  I think my image looks like those. :(   Not only am I terrifed of yet another life-threatening disease, but I'm kicking myself for not taking better care of myself, for not getting mammos earlier, etc., etc.  I should have known better. I'm sorry this is so long.  I don't have too many people to talk to. Dx 8/17/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 9/14/2011 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel Surgery 10/17/2011 Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary Chemotherapy 12/19/2011 CMF Radiation Therapy 5/7/2012 Hormonal Therapy 6/19/2012 Femara (letrozole) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 07:55PM etherize wrote: truebff, I wish I could tell you it gets better soon, but I'm in the same boat as you. The booklet they sent me home with says the pain can "increase in the weeks" following surgery and this is definitely the case with me.  I'm assuming it's just that the nerves are "coming back to life."  It also says that gently stroking the area can "sometimes" reduce the sensitivity. I had my lumpectomy and SNB 8 days ago, and the skin on my side, under my arm and my armpit is so painfully sensitive.  I ran out of my post-surgery pain meds, and haven't asked to get a renewal, since I'm sure they'll give me grief about it. When I was allowed to take a shower (3 days after surgery), most of the big gauze bandage came off, but a piece of the adhesive on my side under my arm was stuck on SO tightly .... It took me 40 minutes of rubbing the skin on my side (VERY gently!) with acetone just to get it off!  I couldn't leave it on, because then my arm would stick to my side.  As it is, there is STILL a tiny bit of adhesive there ... it's just too painful to rub alcohol or acetone or soap or anything on it for very long.  So every day, it's just a little bit less sticky. ;)  BTW, this is all a pretty good distance from the actual incision, in case anybody's freaked about me getting nail polish remover in the incision! Tomorrow I meet with the BS for the post-op and I'm afraid she's going to want to touch something!  I still have the steri-strips on.  I didn't realize until today that they're actually GLUED on.  Do they just yank those off, or what?  I'll run screaming from her office if she tries it!  LOL

Posts.Title: Dumped my MO etherize etherize

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2012 04:00PM etherize wrote: I'll chime in on the benefits of medical marijuana over Xanax and god forbid, Ativan.  There is some evidence that poor growing conditions (like what you get from backyard growers) can result in mold and this is what causes that self-conscious "paranoid" feeling.  I live in California and have a medical marijuana card and the cannabis I've bought from dispensaries does not cause that side effect.  You also need to be sure you start slowly and don't smoke too much. ;)  I can take one puff and it's enough to distract my mind from anxiety-provoking issues -- a much better alternative to a long-acting pharmaceutical.     Ativan is a short-acting benzodiazepine and it can be very, very addictive and very hard (and dangerous!) to withdraw from.  I know from experience and would NOT recommend it to anybody to take long-term.  It can be a life-saver for a single event (like a surgery, or chemo infusions) but if you get anxiety attacks regularly, and you don't like to take pills anyway, I think looking into cannabis is a good alternative. Somebody mentioned marijuana can be a "slippery slope" -- but all these prescription drugs can be, too. ;)

Posts.Title: Has anyone started a Dec 2011 group? darlam mamabee

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2012 08:46PM etherize wrote: I was also surprised that there wasn't just one surgery -- not for me, anyway.  And like you, I thought about getting a double mastectomy, too.  But I'm glad I didn't.  The lumpectomy and the axillary lymph node dissection (where they took out a bunch more lymph nodes) were enough surgeries for me. Getting radiation doesn't hurt the chances of getting future surgeries.  It just means you can't get radiation on the same breast if the cancer came back there; at that point you'd have to have a mastectomy.  You can't have radiation twice in the same place.  But if you keep your breast(s) now, you could have surgery on them later if needed.

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2011 08:51PM - edited Nov 7, 2011 08:54PM by etherize For what it's worth, my MO (who is very smart and worked at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center) said Oncotype is not as powerful a predictor as it's made out to be.   He said Mammaprint is much better.  You have to order it before your surgery, so they can prepare the specimen correctly.  There's more info on it here:  http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/testing/types/mammaprint.jsp I don't know if your insurance would cover it, but it's worth asking about.  Good luck! Oh, and Oncotype CAN be done if you have one positive node (it was offered to me) ... they're currently doing a study on node-positive women (I think postmenopausal) and Oncotype.
Posts.Title: Should we have the OncotypeDX test done? pupmom WaveWhisperer

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2012 08:14PM etherize wrote: marie5890, thanks for saying I'm a wonderful lady. :-D StayinAlive, why put yourself through a double mastectomy?  I can't imagine any doctor would recommend it in your case, with a non-aggressive (Grade 1) DCIS tumor.  I'm in a support group with several women who had tumors like yours and none had mastectomies, much less doubles.  There was one woman whose tumor was so small they didn't have enough tissue to test.  But unfortunately, I don't know what she chose for treatment after the lumpectomy; she hasn't been back to the group when I've been there. Cancer is so different from HIV.  It's a b**** to have both.  My heart goes out to you, fellow survivor!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with BC. AIDS for 20+yrs. StayinAlive68 Shachar

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2011 11:23PM etherize wrote: CindyT, I feel for you!   I too have a lot of fear, as I guess everybody does in the beginning and at times along the way.  While I don't know the stage or grade of my tumor, I was given a choice between mast and lump with radiation.  I'll definitely have hormone (anti-hormone, really) therapy too because my tumor is HER2-, but I don't know yet about chemo (depends on what they find with the lump).   It was hard to decide between lump and mast, but one big factor for me was thinking about recovery time and my overall health.  I felt that because of my other health issues, and extreme squeamishness about surgery, etc. that a lumpectomy was best for me.  My BS was recommending it, and she impressed me as somebody who is very knowledgeable and caring.  So there's the trust factor that you have with your doctors as well. Many women want to conserve as much of their breast as possible, so they lean toward a lump, while others feel safer with a mast (MX) and possibly reconstruction.   As you know, with a lump you will have radiation.  Some people really, really, really want to avoid radiation at all costs, and that's a factor in them deciding on a mast, where the chance of still having to have radiation is very small.  For me, rad is not a big deal, so that weighed in favor of a lump.  Anyway, just take all these factors and break them down one at a time -- pros and cons.  Read up on each and ask questions here.  You might even write it all down so it's easier to work through. And as many people have said, it isn't as much of a rush as it feels like! ;-) Oh, one last thing to answer your question about hormones and being postmenopausal, which I am too.  I learned that it's not just the ovaries that make estrogen ... so even though we've gone through menopause, we're still making estrogen. :-)
Posts.Title: Fear CindyT jazz3000

Posts.Content: etherize wrote: 48 hours from now I'll be under the knife!  Before that, the injection(s?), the wires, etc.  After, everything changes ... I can't imagine I will ever feel OK again, not with my medical history. I've been doing pretty well up to now (it's been almost a MONTH since I was dx'd!  I know that's not uncommon but sheesh ... talk about the torture of waiting/not knowing) ... Anyway, I've able to get involved with other things, distract myself a bit.  But I woke up this morning practically hyperventilating.  I can't think of anything else, or settle down.  It doesn't help that I keep getting calls and postcards reminding me of these appointments and when they're going to inject stuff, and ... etc., etc. I keep wondering why they said they "think" it's an early stage ... At 1.8-2.9cm (on mammo/u-s), that seems pretty big for an "early" stage.  They don't know the grade, either.  I wonder if they just said that so I wouldn't freak out.  I feel like I have to prepare myself for a possible stage IV or at best, late stage III.  Sorry for rambling on ... nobody to talk to here, and it's all getting very real.  Dx 8/17/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 9/14/2011 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel Surgery 10/17/2011 Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary Chemotherapy 12/19/2011 CMF Radiation Therapy 5/7/2012 Hormonal Therapy 6/19/2012 Femara (letrozole) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: So nervous! etherize etherize

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2011 08:45PM etherize wrote: Thank you, LisaAlissa, Yes, I'm having a wire loc because in addition to the big, palpable painful lump there is a "spot" they want to remove.  And yes, also a SNB.  Fortunately, my BS is familiar with the new research (which I'd found on the internet before meeting her, so I'd asked about it).  She doesn't want to create more risk of lymphedema with little long-term benefit, so she said they "probably wouldn't" remove more nodes. And I have actually read the pages on staging ... so I guess I do "know" it "could" be Stage I or II ... but somehow ... I've had enough PTSD from previous health issues to fear the absolute worst. Seems to be my luck.  Just fear speaking here. :) All the cutting, injections, pain and post-op recovery is what makes me really nervous, not to mention imagining the long road ahead (which I know I "shouldn't" imagine but can't help it).  I feel fairly confident in my BS (as confident as one can be in a well-educated but complete stranger).  It's just the process of going through it all that has me on edge. I am getting a lot of "deep breathing" practice in, though -- that's for sure! ;)
Posts.Title: So nervous! etherize etherize

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2012 04:00PM etherize wrote: Hi Gail35, I'm sorry to hear you're going through this.  I don't know anything about focal asymmetry but to answer your question, a needle biopsy can indeed find cancer in the duct.  Invasive ductal carcinoma (cancer in the duct) is one of the most common types of breast cancer. You're a long way from that conclusion, though, so try not to panic (easier said than done, I know).  It's good that you're following through on this, given your concerns about your family history. Do ask your doctor about this procedure that checks the ducts -- it's something I've never heard of, so can't give you info on that.  Do you know what it's called?
Posts.Title: Don't know what to do Gail35 etherize
